message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by genetic abnormalities on chromosome 15, which can result from a deletion on the maternal chromosome, a paternal uniparental disomy (inheritance of two copies of the chromosome from the father and none from the mother), an imprinting defect (where the maternal copy of the chromosome is not methylated), or a mutation in the UBE3A gene. Among the options, uniparental disomy best describes the mechanism for the disorder in the child.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by the absence or malfunction of a gene on chromosome 15 inherited from the mother, or by a deletion in that region of the chromosome. Uniparental disomy refers to the situation where both copies of a chromosome are inherited from a single parent, which can occur in the case of Angelman syndrome. Codominance and incomplete penetrance do not apply to this situation. Variable expressivity refers to the range of symptoms displayed by individuals with the same genetic disorder, and while this is true for Angelman syndrome, it does not directly explain the genetic mechanism behind it.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by loss of function of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15q11.2-q13, while the paternal copy is normally imprinted and silenced. However, in some cases, there can be uniparental disomy, where two copies of the chromosome come from one parent instead of one from each parent. This can lead to homozygosity or hemizygosity for the mutant allele, resulting in expression of the disease phenotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene, or by paternal uniparental disomy, which means both copies of the gene come from the father. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) uniparental disomy. Codominance refers to a situation where both alleles in a gene pair are expressed equally, incomplete penetrance refers to a situation where a person has a gene but does not express the phenotype, and variable expressivity refers to the degree to which a particular phenotype is expressed in different individuals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by the loss or inactivation of genes on the maternal chromosome 15, while the paternal chromosome 15 is normal. This abnormality is known as uniparental disomy, where two copies of a chromosome come from one parent and no copies come from the other parent. Codominance involves both alleles being expressed equally, incomplete penetrance is when a gene mutation is present but does not always result in a particular phenotype, and variable expressivity is when the same genotype can manifest with different phenotypes. None of these terms accurately describe the mechanism for Angelman syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15. However, in rare cases, it can be caused by uniparental disomy, in which both copies of the gene come from the father instead of one from each parent. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Codominance refers to a situation where both alleles in a heterozygous individual are expressed equally. Incomplete penetrance refers to a situation where individuals with a certain genotype do not always express the phenotype. Variable expressivity refers to a situation where individuals with the same genotype express the phenotype with varying degrees of severity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by loss of function of the UBE3A gene on the maternal allele of chromosome 15. Uniparental disomy, which occurs when a person inherits two copies of a chromosome from one parent and none from the other, can result in Angelman syndrome if the UBE3A gene on the maternal chromosome 15 is affected. Codominance, incomplete penetrance, and variable expressivity do not fit the mechanism of Angelman syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by the loss of function of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene in chromosome 15 due to uniparental disomy, meaning the child inherited two copies of the chromosome 15 from the father and none from the mother. Codominance involves both alleles being expressed equally, incomplete penetrance involves the presence of a gene mutation but not all individuals with it will show the phenotype, and variable expressivity involves varying degrees of expression of a phenotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15, or by paternal uniparental disomy (inherited two copies of the paternal chromosome 15). Therefore, the best genetic term to describe the mechanism for this disorder is uniparental disomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or mutation of the maternal UBE3A gene or through uniparental disomy, meaning both copies of chromosome 15 are inherited from the father instead of one from each parent. Therefore, the best genetic term to describe the mechanism for this disorder is uniparental disomy.
